title: Carola Veit
text:
Carola Alexandra Veit (born 2 June 1973 in <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>) is a <a href="Germans">German</a> <a href="politician">politician</a> who has been <a href="President%20of%20the%20Hamburg%20Parliament">president</a> of the <a href="Hamburg%20Parliament">Hamburg Parliament</a> since 23 March 2011.
Early career.
Having grown up in Hamburg's <a href="Billstedt">Billstedt</a> district, Veit trained as a paralegal then a lawyer. 
Political career.
Veit became a member of the <a href="Social%20Democratic%20Party%20of%20Germany">SPD</a> in 1991 and a member of the Hamburg Mitte District Board in 2000.
Since 2004, Veit has been a member of the Hamburg Parliament for the SPD. She has since been serving on several committees such as the Committee on Families, Children and Youth and the Committee on Constitutional Matters. In the 20th session of the parliament (2011–2015) she was elected <a href="President%20of%20the%20Hamburg%20Parliament">President of the Hamburg Parliament</a>. She was re-elected for a further term, 2015–2020, in the 21st session.
In the negotiations to form a "<a href="Grand%20coalition%20%28Germany%29">Grand Coalition</a>" of <a href="Chancellor%20of%20Germany">Chancellor</a> <a href="Angela%20Merkel">Angela Merkel</a>'s Christian Democrats (<a href="Christian%20Democratic%20Union%20%28Germany%29">CDU</a> together with the Bavarian <a href="Christian%20Social%20Union%20of%20Bavaria">CSU</a>) and the SPD following the <a href="2013%20German%20federal%20election">2013 German elections</a>, Veit was part of the SPD delegation in the working group on integration and migration, led by <a href="Maria%20B%C3%B6hmer">Maria Böhmer</a> and <a href="Aydan%20%C3%96zo%C4%9Fuz">Aydan Özoğuz</a>.
In 2015, Veit was appointed Vice Chairman of the <a href="Baltic%20Sea%20Parliamentary%20Conference">Baltic Sea Parliamentary Conference</a> (BSPC). In 2016 she was appointed President of the BSPC. She was a SPD delegate to the <a href="Federal%20Convention%20%28Germany%29">Federal Convention</a> for the purpose of electing the <a href="President%20of%20Germany">President of Germany</a> in 2017 and in <a href="2022%20German%20presidential%20election">2022</a>.
Personal life.
Veit lives in a long-term relationship with an architect. The couple has three children and lives in Hamburg's <a href="Spadenland">Spadenland</a> district.
